post.title: Entrepreneurship: The Ultimate Test of Courage
post.content:
I’m an entrepreneur. The prospect of starting a new adventure gets me up in the morning. You might be the same way. Just thinking about the next business opportunity sends your brain into overdrive.

You were made to be an entrepreneur.

But, let me ask you this. And it’s a question that you seriously need to consider. Do you have the balls to get through the first year of your business? Because if you don’t, you probably shouldn’t start.

Let that sink in.

Starting a business takes courage. If you’ve already done it, I applaud you. If you’re getting ready to go all-in, be ready for the ultimate test.

In the first year of my start-up, I learned that the business would never survive without the grit and sheer determination. This was especially true when it came to finances.

The Ultimate Test

We had officially launched our business and had acquired a relatively big contract. Along with getting equipment, we had done the difficult work of planning an infrastructure that could handle exponential growth  But, what I quickly discovered was the personal sacrifice I would have to make for the business to grow and sustain itself for the long-haul.

Having a big contract meant that we had to purchase equipment and hire employees before the client made a single payment. Don’t get me wrong. I’m not complaining. It was incredible that we had such a huge contract from the beginning. But, for the first 60 days, our company had zero cash flow. ZERO.

I started thinking to myself, “Was it a good idea to start this business? Am I cut out for this? How am I going to survive without a paycheck? All of my friends are taking vacations to Mexico and I’m stuck here grinding!”

When those thoughts started flooding in, I could have given up. I could have thrown in the towel and decided to give up on my dream.

Have you been there before? If not, you will.

Instead of quitting, I took a second job to support myself while the company grew. My dad, who worked with me, did the same thing. Neither of us took a paycheck for 7 months.

Every single dollar that came in was put back into the business. Every. Single. Dollar.

“Starting a business takes courage. If you’ve already done it, I applaud you. If you’re getting ready to go all in, be ready for the ultimate test..”

You Have What It Takes

Now let me ask you again. Do you have the balls to be an entrepreneur?

Could you work two jobs for 7 months only getting paid for one? Could you survive without money while your buddies from college buy new cars and houses?

Experts will tell you that most start-ups fail within 3 years. Why is that the case? I believe it’s for two reasons. Lack of cash and lack of courage.

So, I write this to encourage you, not to defeat you. If the thought of starting a new business gets you up in the morning, you were made to be an entrepreneur. I believe in you and am proud of you for making a leap that few people have the grit to make.

Here’s my advice. When you’re tempted to give up. When you’re tempted to cut your losses and run. Don’t.

Put the money back into the business, eat Ramen noodles for every meal, so that you can look back after a decade and see what was built by your courage and ability to push through when it’s tough.

Long-game thinking is how you build a business that lasts for generations.

When it comes to starting a business, what makes you the most afraid?

How have you overcome challenges in the past? What did you learn from that experience?

Do you believe you have what it takes to start a business? Spend a moment writing down why you believe you were made to be an entrepreneur. Tear out the piece of paper and put it in a place you’ll see every day.
